abstract.text: 55 The Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) has caused thousands of 56 deaths worldwide, including >18,000 in New York City (NYC) alone. The sudden emergence of 57 this pandemic has highlighted a pressing clinical need for rapid, scalable diagnostics that can 58 detect infection, interrogate strain evolution, and identify novel patient biomarkers. To address 59 these challenges, we designed a fast (30-minute) colorimetric test (LAMP) for SARS-CoV-2 60 infection from naso/oropharyngeal swabs, plus a large-scale shotgun metatranscriptomics 61 platform (total-RNA-seq) for host, bacterial, and viral profiling. We applied both technologies 62 across 857 SARS-CoV-2 clinical specimens and 86 NYC subway samples, providing a broad 63 molecular portrait of the COVID-19 NYC outbreak. Our results define new features of SARS-64 CoV-2 evolution, nominate a novel, NYC-enriched viral subclade, reveal specific host responses 65 in interferon, ACE, hematological, and olfaction pathways, and examine risks associated with 66 use of ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers. Together, these findings have 67 immediate applications to SARS-CoV-2 diagnostics, public health, and new therapeutic targets. 68 69

body_text.text: In March 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) declared a pandemic of the coronavirus 76 disease 2019 (COVID-19), an infection caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 77 2 (SARS-CoV-2) (He et al., 2020) . Since its start, more than three million of cases and more 78 than two hundred of thousand deaths have been reported (https://coronavirus.jhu.edu), with an 79 especially high burden in New York City (NYC). Since the presenting symptoms of COVID-19 80
body_text.section: Introduction 75

body_text.text: can resemble those of common viral respiratory infections, a molecular diagnosis is required to 81
body_text.section: Introduction 75

body_text.text: reliably distinguish a SARS-CoV-2 infection from influenza and other respiratory illnesses 82 (Guan et al., 2020 , Zhou et al., 2020 . 83 84
body_text.section: Introduction 75

body_text.text: The current gold standard (qRT-PCR-based) approaches to SARS-CoV-2 molecular testing are 85 largely limited to hospital or academic laboratories and reserved for the most severe cases, with 86 limited accessibility to the general public. As a result, the true prevalence of SARS-CoV-2 in the 87 population is mostly unknown, particularly among pre-symptomatic, mild symptomatic, or 88 asymptomatic cases. Though several novel, scalable biotechnological approaches for viral testing 89 have recently emerged (e.g., CRISPR-Cas12a (Broughton et al., 2020) Related pathogens, high prevalence disease agents, and normal or pathogenic microbiota that are 139 reasonably likely to be encountered in the clinical samples were evaluated to identify the percent 140 homology between the primer sequences and these other organisms, and the probes were also 141 designed to avoid known polymorphisms (see Methods). 142 143 To validate the assay, we first evaluated two synthetic RNAs (see Methods) whose sequences 144 matched the viral sequences of patients from Wuhan, China and Melbourne, Australia (Supp. 145 Fig. 1 ). The first control (MT007544.1) was used to test the analytical sensitivity via the limit of 146 detection (LoD), titrated from 1 million molecules of virus (10 6 ) down to a single copy, using 147 serial log10 dilutions. The reaction output was measured at 0-, 20-, and 30-minute intervals 148 (Figure 1c, Supp. Figure 2a) before the samples were heated to 95 o C for inactivation. LAMP 149 fluorescence correlated closely with SARS-CoV-2 RNA viral copies (Figure 1d) , with an 150 overlap of the median signal from negative controls at lower levels (0-10 total copies per 151 reaction) of viral RNA (n=10). The LoD was found to be between 5-25 viral total copies for the 152 dual primer, single-tube reaction (N gene and E gene), and this was then replicated to show a 153 similar LoD on the second synthetic control from a patient from Wuhan (Supp. Figure 2b, 3a) . 154 155
body_text.section: Introduction 75

body_text.text: To optimize the LAMP assay for clinical samples, we first tested the reaction on a range of 156 sample types, dilutions, and reaction volumes. We used a set of 201 samples from known or 157
body_text.section: Introduction 75

body_text.text: suspected COVID-19 cases that were tested for SARS-CoV-2 by a commercial qRT-PCR assay 158 that has been the primary clinical test at NYPH-WCMC since early March. These comprised 69 159 nasopharyngeal (NP) swab samples that tested positive (qRT-PCR positives, Ct<40) and 132 160 samples that tested negative (qRT-PCR negative, Ct ≥ 40) (see Methods). qRT-PCR positive 161 samples showed a much higher LAMP fluorescence than qRT-PCR negative samples, with 162
body_text.section: Introduction 75

body_text.text: superior performance observed at higher (10µL vs 5µL) input volumes (Supp. Figure 3b) . PCR positive samples that failed to generate LAMP fluorescence were associated with lower 164 viral genome abundance (high cycle threshold [Ct] value qRT-PCR). We obtained similar 165 performance on bulk oropharyngeal swab lysate (Supp. Analysis of Receiver Operator Characteristic (ROC) curves revealed an optimal threshold of 172 11,140 QuantiFluor relative fluorescence units (RFUs), which yielded an overall sensitivity of 173 95.6% and specificity of 99.2% (Figure 1e) . We observed higher LAMP sensitivity at higher 174 viral loads, as determined by qRT-PCR Ct values (Supp. Fig. 4) . The highest viral load (Ct <20) 175 showed 100.0% sensitivity and 97.4% specificity, compared with the sensitivity at the lowest 176 viral load at 80.0% (Ct >28, RFU below 7010). These same LAMP assay thresholds yielded 177 consistent test positivity for synthetic RNA positive controls (Twist Biosciences) as well as 178 clinical spike-in carrier RNAs (20/20) (Supp. Fig. 4) , and consistent signal from clinical viral 179 positives in Vero E6 cells (100.0%, 12/12) and blank clinical buffer negatives (100.0% 8/8). 180 181
body_text.section: Introduction 75

body_text.text: Shotgun metatranscriptomics platform for viral, microbiome, and host genomics 182 To provide orthogonal validation of our LAMP assay and further investigate the biological 183 characteristics of qRT-PCR positive and negative specimens, we developed a shotgun 184 metatranscriptomics platform utilizing total RNA-seq (RNA-sequencing with ribosomal RNA 185 depletion) to profile all RNAs from patient and environmental swab specimens (Figure 1a) . We 186 sequenced 857 RNA-seq libraries (Figure 2) Figure  202 5a), as well as RNA-seq extraction replicates (Supp. Figure 5b) . These results provide 203 additional validation for the LAMP SARS-CoV-2 assay on clinical samples. 204 205
body_text.section: Introduction 75

body_text.text: Analysis of total RNA-seq sequences also enabled mapping of likely co-infections and 206 colonization with commensal species across both clinical positives and negatives in our sample 207 set. We identified additional RNA viruses and organisms that distinguished high, medium, and 208 lower viral load patients (Supp Table 1 , Supp. Figure 6) , with overall similarity observed 209 across patients in the bacterial RNA fractions (Supp. Figure 7a) . However, a broad range of other 232 bacterial and viral species was found, including a large set of phages (e.g. Streptomyces phage 233 VWB), desiccation-tolerant bacteria (e.g Deinococcus radiodurans), and more abundant 234 bacterial and archaeal RNA than the clinical samples (Supp . Table 1) . Of note, these were 235 checked against a database of putative false positives (Supp . Table 2) , which was created from 236

body_text.text: Taken together, these results indicate that high transit surfaces were not likely to harbor 238 significant levels of SARS-CoV-2 in the early phases of the NYC epidemic. 239 240 SARS-CoV-2 assemblies from shotgun metatranscriptomes 241
body_text.section: Introduction 75

body_text.text: The abundance of SARS-CoV-2 alignments from total RNA-seq was sufficient to provide >10x 242 coverage of the viral genomes and yield high quality, full-length assemblies for 155 samples, 243
body_text.section: Introduction 75

body_text.text: including 146 (67.6%) of qRT-PCR positive patient samples (Figure 3a, Supp. Figure 6) . The 244 97 qRT-PCR positive samples that yielded partial or no assembly demonstrated low or uneven 245 genome-wide read depth, though these were increased on average relative to qRT-PCR 246 negatives. We also generated full length SARS-CoV-2 assemblies for 9 samples that were found 247 negative by qRT-PCR (Figure 3a) . Each of these demonstrated a high RPKM viral load, an 248 abundance of reads evenly covering the SARS-CoV-2 genome, and high (>0.5) variant allele 249 fractions (VAFs) of SNV's commonly seen in positive samples, as well as a recent build of 250 GISAID (Figure 3b) . Apart from these common variant sites, we did not find additional 251 recurrent mutations that might explain why these cases were not detected by qRT-PCR (e.g. 252 primer site mutation Analysis of VAF posterior probability distributions identified a subset of alleles whose VAFs 259
body_text.section: Introduction 75

body_text.text: were confidently (probability > 0.95) above 0.05 but below 0.95. We labeled these alleles as 260
body_text.section: Introduction 75

body_text.text: "het" (heterogenous) variants and refer to the remaining (high VAF) consensus assembly variants 261 as "homogeneous." Many of these het variants were associated with robust read support despite 262 frequently having VAFs below 0.5 and not being incorporated into the consensus assembly 263 sequence. A subset of samples (11/155) samples harbored at least 5 het variants, with a 264 significant enrichment (P = 0.0054) in qRT-PCR negative cases (Figure 3c) . Analyzing the 265 population allele frequencies (PAF) of these het variants across GISAID revealed the vast 266 majority (91%) to be rare (PAF<0.1) or even private to that sample, indicating that these were 267 unlikely to be due to cross contamination (Figure 3d ). 268 269
body_text.section: Introduction 75

body_text.text: We then asked whether het variants might indicate the presence of a viral subclone, arising either 270 through co-infection or intra-host adaptation. Analyzing het-rich (>5 het variants) samples, 271 revealed that set of het variants observed in a single sample showed similar VAFs, yielding clear 272 peaks when summing their individual posterior probability densities (Figure 3e) . These results 273
body_text.section: Introduction 75

body_text.text: were consistent with the presence of a viral subclone at some fraction f corresponding to the 274 modes of each of these VAF distributions (0.1-0.2). Interestingly, each of the three samples 275
body_text.section: Introduction 75

body_text.text: shown in Figure 3e also harbored a clear peak of homogenous variants with VAFs near 1. These 276 results suggest that the viral subclone is not the result of a coinfection by two viruses, which 277 would yield a second peak at 1-f at every major clone variant that has the reference allele in the 278 minor subclone. Het variants were found to occur at common sites of consensus variants across 279 samples, however, rare private hets were also present (Figure 3f ).
body_text.section: Introduction 75

body_text.text: Global phylogenetic relationship of NYC strains 282 We next integrated 141 full-length NYPH-WCMC sequences with 7,806 SARS-CoV-2 283 sequences obtained from a recent GISAID build (downloaded on 4/20/2020) into a maximum 284 likelihood phylogenetic tree using the Nextstrain algorithm (Hadfield et the "L" strain, which is defined by a reference base at position 28143 (ORF8) and previously 293 associated with severe cases in Wuhan (Tang et al., 2020) (Figure 4b ).
Among the A2 cases in our cohort, we found a recurrent 9 bp in-frame deletion (g.686_694del) 296

in the gene encoding non-structural protein 1 (NSP1). NSP1 is a putative SARS-CoV-2 virulence 297 factor that is highly divergent across betacoronaviruses (Narayanan et al., 2015) . This deletion 298 was assembled in 3 of 93 NYPH-WCMC samples, in which it showed robust read support with 299 near >0.95 VAF across thousands of high-quality alignments to the locus (Figure 4c ). An 300 identical deletion was observed in 15 other samples in the GISAID database, spanning samples 301 from England, Iceland, and Canada, as well as three additional cases from New York. Among 302 these, 12 of 15 were labeled as part of clade A2 by Nextstrain, while two (Washington state) 303 cases were associated with a distant clade B1 (Figure 4d ). This deletion removes three amino 304 acids (p.141_143KSD), including a residue that is variant (143Y>F) relative to the SARS-CoV-1 305 genome (Figure 4c ). Interestingly, a 16th case (Washington, clade A2, Figure 4c ) showed a 306 related but not identical 9 bp in-frame deletion (g.686_694del) that removes the same three 307 residues. These residues occur in a conserved portion of the C-terminal region of NSP1, which 308 has been linked to host chemokine dysregulation and translational inhibition in SARS-CoV 309 (Narayanan et al., 2015) .
Given the predominance of clade A2 among NYC cases, we next asked whether specific variants 313
body_text.section: 311 A novel SARS-CoV-2 subclade enriched in NYC cases 312

body_text.text: were enriched in NYC A2 samples relative to other regions' A2 samples. Comparing variant 314 frequencies between A2 cases in our data and non-NYC cases in GISAID, we identified six 315 enriched loci with FDR<0.1 (Fisher's exact test, one-tailed) that were over-represented in NYC 316 A2 samples (Figure 5a ). All six of these variants were significantly enriched (Bonferroni-317 adjusted p-value <0.05) in a second analysis comparing all other cases from NYC in GISAID vs. 318 the rest of the world (Figure 5a) . Visualizing the most significant of these variants across the 319
body_text.section: 311 A novel SARS-CoV-2 subclade enriched in NYC cases 312

body_text.text: Nextstrain derived phylogenetic tree (Figure 5b ) demonstrated that the highest frequency of 320 these variants (25563G>T), defined a novel subclade of A2, which we call A2-25563. This 321 subclade comprised 84.4% (572/678) of (NYPH-WCMC and GISAID) NYC samples, and 322 92.7% (572/617) of the A2 portion of NYC cases (Sinai and NYU). Interestingly, while all three 323 of the NYPH-WCMC A2 cases harboring the aforementioned NSP1 9-bp deletion were in A2-324 25563, many of the remaining cases were distributed across other subclades. Unlike the SNVs 325 used to define A2-25563, this deletion appeared to be highly polyphyletic with 7 unique 326 phylogenetic clusters associated with the deletion across a variety of clades (Figure 4c , Figure  327 5b). 328 329
body_text.section: 311 A novel SARS-CoV-2 subclade enriched in NYC cases 312

body_text.text: Investigating the geographical and temporal distribution of non-NYC samples in A2-25563, we 330
body_text.section: 311 A novel SARS-CoV-2 subclade enriched in NYC cases 312

body_text.text: found a global distribution with likely origin in Western Europe (Figure 5c, 5d) . The first noted 331 case of A2-25563 in GISAID was in Belgium on 2/21/2020, but since then, this putative 332 subclade has represented a minority (20%) of Western European cases. While the prevalence of 333 A2-25563 in NYC appeared to be consistently high across sampling dates, it constituted only a 334 moderate proportion of cases from the Western and (non-New York portion of the) Eastern USA 335 (<50%) in early March (Figure 5d) . Strikingly, we found that of the prevalence of the A2-25563 336 clade across Eastern and Western United States steadily and significantly increased through late 337
body_text.section: 311 A novel SARS-CoV-2 subclade enriched in NYC cases 312

body_text.text: March and early April, while remaining stable in the Midwest. Among the early locations 338
body_text.section: 311 A novel SARS-CoV-2 subclade enriched in NYC cases 312

body_text.text: showing high fractions of A2-25563 was West Africa, which has steadily decreased in 339 prevalence since early March (Figure 5d ). The SNVs defining A2-25563 subclade were non-340 synonymous variants targeting genes encoding the non-structural protein 2 (NSP2), the viral 341 replicase, and ORF3a, a poorly characterized SARS-CoV-2 protein with putative roles in 342
body_text.section: 311 A novel SARS-CoV-2 subclade enriched in NYC cases 312

body_text.text: inflammation (Siu et al., 2019) . This subclade defining ORF3a site (p.Gln57His) is distinct from 343 that which defines the previously characterized L strain (p.Leu84Ser) (Tang et al., 2020) . 344 345

body_text.text: Defining the SARS-CoV-2 host transcriptome 346 We leveraged the comprehensive nature of the total RNA-seq profiles to better understand the 347 host transcriptome during SARS-CoV-2 infection. Cell proportion analyses using the MUSIC 348 deconvolution algorithm showed enriched proportions of cell types spanning goblet, ciliated 349 airway, and epithelial cells across all samples (Supp. Figure 9 ). Differentially expressed genes 350

These spanned viral response pathways, innate immune 356 response, and interferon signaling (Figure 6b ,d, Supp. Figure 10a ), but also included iron, 357 olfaction, calcium, and ribosome dysregulation. 358 359

body_text.text: Differentially expressed host genes indicated a wide range of antiviral responses, including a 360 common interferon response across all ranges of viral levels, which was significantly higher 361 when compared to SARS-CoV-2 negative samples that harbored other respiratory viruses 362 (Figure 6a,b) . Notably, host cells showed an increase in angiotensin converting enzyme 2 363 (ACE2) expression (Figure 6b ) (p-value=1.4x10 -9 ), which is the SARS-CoV-2 cellular receptor 364 (Hoffmann et al., 2020) . Also, a subset of cytokines (CXCL10, 371 CXCL11, CCL8) showed the highest spike of expression in the higher viral load sub-group 372 (Supp. Figure 10) , matching previous results from animal models and infected cells (Blanco-373 Melo et al., 2020). body_text.text: Though previous epidemiological studies have reported increased mortality and morbidity in 511 COVID-19 patients with hypertension, we sought to examine this risk in the context of ACEI or 512 ARB use (Patel and Verma, 2020) . Our retrospective clinical analysis shows that ACEI/ARB 513 exposure increased COVID-19 risk, but showed equivocal effects for morbidity and mortality 514 when conditioning on hypertension status. A recent study reported a protective effect of 515 ACEI/ARB exposure on mortality . We were able to replicate their result by 516 conditioning on hypertension. However, this same analysis also revealed no effect, or possibly 517 even a risk, from ACEI/ARB exposure on mechanical respiration and a strong risk of infection. 518

body_text.text: Our cohort data for SARS-CoV-2 suspected patients is extracted from the electronic health 882 records at NYPH-CUIMC. In addition, we used data from 90,989 patients, who were not tested for SARS-CoV-884 2 infection and were 18 years or older, with available electronic health records from January 1st, 885 2019 through September 24th, 2019 to represent a comparison population of patients. body_text.text: With increasing viral load, as measured by qRT-PCR, the LAMP assay shows an increased sensitivity (y-axis) and specificity (y-axis). We found no risk in the 431 larger cohort nor for any other single ARB (Supp. Figure 13, with complete modeling results 432 are provided in Supplemental Tables 6-9). 433 434 Discussion 435 During a large-scale pandemic with exponential spread, such as COVID-19, scalable methods for 436 diagnosis and screening are crucial for both mitigation and containment (Lan et al., 2020, Liu et 437 al., 2020). While hospital-grade, core lab devices can achieve massive throughput (thousands of 438 samples per day), a key limitation of these assays is accessibility of testing facilities to patients, 439 the logistics of sample transport, and timely test reporting. These limitations become even more 440 stark in the context of widespread quarantines and nationwide lockdowns, where requiring 441 patients to travel (even for viral testing) incurs significant personal and public health risks. 442 443

TABREF8.text: 451 Specifically, LAMP positivity may quickly indicate if an area is infectious and a negative result 452(with appropriate confirmation) will possibly represent a lower risk. Indeed, these tools and 453 methods can help create a viral "weather report" if broadly used and partnered with continual 454 validation. 455 456Total RNA-sequencing data enabled a complete genetic map of the viruses in a significant subset 457 of our samples. Remarkably, we found 9 qRT-PCR negative cases among the 155 cases that had 458 sufficient reads to assemble the SARS-CoV-2 genome de novo. Though these likely qRT-PCR 459 false negatives could not be attributed to specific sequence changes (e.g. primer site mutations), 460 their high frequency underscores the limitation of "gold standard" qRT-PCR approaches for 461 SARS-CoV-2 detection. These results further highlight the need for open-source primer design 462(the RT-PCR methods for this FDA-approved test are proprietary), so these assays can be 463 updated as a more granular picture of strain diversity and evolution is obtained through of strains within this subclade. The first possibility may be potentially 477 linked to expansion among cases in the New Rochelle cluster, though additional genotyping 478 and/or metadata aggregation from those sequenced cases would be required to assess this 479 hypothesis. The third possibility could be consistent with A2-25563 harboring differential 480 fitness with respect to transmissibility or virulence relative to other A2 viruses. 481 482Future studies correlating viral genotypes with patient outcomes in larger cohorts will be 483 necessary to determine whether any of these A2-25563 associated variants functionally influence 484 viral transmission or disease severity. The polyphyletic pattern and convergent evolution pattern 485 observed with NSP1 p.141_143KSD, including clades outside of A2, raises the possibility that 486 this variant arose multiple times and may be under positive selection. Given the small number of 487 these variants observed in our analysis (14), larger and more statistically powered datasets will 488 be required to evaluate this hypothesis. The VAF distribution in patients harboring het variants 489suggests that intrahost diversification may lead to the development of SARS-CoV-2 subclones in 490 a subset of COVID-19 cases. ACEI/ARBs Multivariate and Comparative Analyses. Comparison of the effects of different ACEIs (benazepril, enalapril, lisinopril, ramipril) and ARBs (losartan, olmesartan, telmisartan, valsartan) when compared to patients exposed to other ACEIs or ARBs, respectively. There were no significant findings amongst the different ACEIs. However, among the ARBs we found that olmesartan was associated with a significant increase in mortality (HR=2.3 CI: 1.1-4.9, p=3.05E-02).
